proposals.reasoning: Bob is widely accepted as a reasonable early pick, and pairing him with me (Eve) matches the most organically formed consensus that wasn’t pre-shaped around Diana. This avoids the early Bob+Diana push that felt steered, gives us a clean, low-drama first info-gathering mission, and doesn’t prematurely treat anyone as confirmed based on discussion alone.

votes.comment: Early 2-person mission gives useful info without overly clearing anyone, and there’s no strong reason yet to distrust this pair more than alternatives.
I’m on it, Eve’s reasonably placed, and this is a fine low-risk first mission for information even if it’s not guaranteed clean.
Keeps both known evil candidates (from the early Bob+Diana push) off the first mission and uses two relatively uncontroversial picks for a clean info-gathering start.
This matches what I advocated earlier (Bob plus a quieter player) and looks like a natural consensus team rather than a forced pairing, so rejecting it would be inconsistent and suspicious.
Early 2-player mission with me on it gives clean info and avoids the pre-shaped Bob+Diana push; good team for round 1 data.
I already argued this is the cleanest, least pre-shaped info team; rejecting now would be inconsistent and draw suspicion.
Solid low-risk info team for M1, avoids the early steered Bob+Diana push and doesn’t over-clear anyone from discussion alone.

discussion.content: Early on I’d rather see a mix of people who’ve actually spoken up, so I’d be okay with something like Bob and Diana, but I don’t think anyone should be treated as “confirmed” this round. Let’s just avoid stacking it with people who are all hard-defending each other already.

I’m fine being on the first team, but I’d like at least one person who hasn’t been heavily defended yet—Diana works for that, and I’m a bit wary of putting Alice on her own suggested team right away. Maybe start with me and Diana, then we adjust based on the result.

I’m a bit hesitant about putting Diana on the first team when most of the early shaping of the discussion is coming from people who like that idea. I’d rather see something like Bob with one of Eve/Frank/Grace so we’re not just following the same pairing everyone’s already nudging toward.

I’m okay not being on the very first team if people are uneasy about it; I’d rather we get a mix that spreads information a bit, like Bob with one of Eve or Frank, and then we can revisit me next round once we’ve seen how that goes.

I like the idea of Bob plus one of the quieter players (I’m fine going myself or seeing Frank go) since that breaks up the early Diana push a bit. I’d rather we avoid any team that feels like it’s forming just because multiple people subtly steered us there.
Bob plus Eve looks like the cleanest info-gathering team to me; the early Bob+Diana focus felt a bit pre-shaped, so I’d rather start with a pair that wasn’t being nudged from the opening posts.
I’m okay with starting with Bob and Eve as a low-drama info team, but whatever happens we shouldn’t treat either of them as cleared off a single 2-person mission.

proposals.reasoning: We keep exactly one of the previously successful pair (Bob/Eve) to avoid auto-locking them, and we avoid running a double-unknown combo like Charlie+Diana that several people disliked. Bob gives us a partially trusted anchor from Mission 1, Charlie is a new test that many have suggested, and I include myself as the third so we’re not pairing two completely untested players together. This follows the general table preference for using one of Bob/Eve plus one of Charlie/Diana, with a third player the table is reasonably comfortable with, while still expanding our information about the rest of the group.

votes.comment: Team structure matches the earlier preference of keeping one from the first mission (Bob) while adding new info (Charlie, Frank), so I’m fine seeing how this plays out.
I know I’m good, and this lineup tests two new players without auto-locking Eve, giving us valuable info early with acceptable risk.
No known evil players on the team; this is a strong, relatively safe test with good info potential.
Frank is on the team, giving evil a strong opportunity to sabotage while the composition still looks reasonable to the table.
Too many unknowns (Charlie and Frank) and it excludes me; I’d prefer a team anchored by Bob+Eve with only one new player added for safer info-gain.
I want to be on the team as evil; having exactly one evil on a 3-player mission keeps options open without immediately looking suspicious.
This fits my earlier preference of keeping exactly one of Bob/Eve and adding Charlie with a third; we need new info, and this is a reasonable, informative team for Mission 2.

discussion.content: Given the first mission was clean, I’d lean toward keeping at least one of Bob or Eve on the next team, but we should mix in someone new like Charlie or Diana so we start getting more info on the rest of the table.

I definitely like the idea of changing it up a bit—I'd be happy to go again, but I’d rather pair myself with two new people than just auto-include Eve. Maybe something like me, Charlie, and Diana so we start testing a wider circle.

If we’re mixing it up, I’d rather keep the proven Bob–Eve pair and just add one new person than swap Eve out or run a double-unknown combo like me and Diana together. That way we get more info without taking an unnecessary risk this early.
I’m more in Bob’s camp here: I’d rather not auto-lock Eve yet, so something like Bob, Charlie, and me feels like a good balance of using a “proven” player while still widening the info net.

From my perspective we should keep at least one of Bob or me on the team—ideally both—and only add one new person, because running two unknowns together (like Charlie and Diana) feels like giving evil an easy shot at sneaking a fail in with very little info gained.

I’m with Bob and Diana on not auto-locking the Bob–Eve pair yet; a team like Bob, Charlie, and Diana feels like a good mix of using the one “proven” player while still actually learning something new.

I’d rather not split off into a double-unknown pair either, so I like the idea of keeping exactly one of Bob/Eve and adding exactly one of Charlie/Diana—something like Bob + Charlie or Bob + Diana with a third we’re comfortable with.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2’s fail came from within the Bob/Charlie/Frank group, so the cleanest way to reduce risk and gain information is to avoid that entire cluster this round. By choosing Eve and me (Grace) plus Alice, we: (1) completely exclude all three players from the failed Mission 2 team, (2) keep only one overlap with the successful Mission 1 team (Eve) without relying on Bob as the sole common factor between success and failure, and (3) form a lineup that, given overall composition, is statistically more likely to be predominantly good while giving us clearer signals about who in the Bob/Charlie/Frank set is suspicious going into Mission 4.

votes.comment: I’m on the team, so from my (evil) perspective this lineup is good to get a chance to sabotage and it also avoids the highly scrutinized Bob/Charlie/Frank cluster, making the outcome easier to muddy.

I know I’m good, so a 3-person team that excludes me while also not including either Charlie or Frank is strictly weaker than a similar team that swaps in me for one of them; I’d rather push for a lineup like Bob+Eve+Alice/Grace instead.

This lineup completely sidelines the entire Bob/Charlie/Frank block from Mission 2, which gives us less ability to resolve where that fail came from. I’d rather see a team that includes at least one of them plus people we’re more comfortable with, instead of a mostly new trio where a single hidden spy could still sink us without clarifying much.

I’d rather not completely ignore the Bob/Charlie/Frank info from Mission 2—this team gives us no direct comparison. I’d prefer a lineup that includes at least one of them (or me) alongside people we’re more comfortable with so we can actually test our suspicions instead of starting from a mostly new group.
This fully avoids the Bob/Charlie/Frank cluster that produced the fail and includes me (known good to myself), making it a low‑risk, high‑info team.
This lineup completely dodges the entire Bob/Charlie/Frank cluster from the failed mission, which gives us very little new comparative info about where the Mission 2 fail came from.

Excludes the entire Bob/Charlie/Frank cluster where we know at least one evil is, and any combination of Eve/Alice/Grace cannot all be evil given Mission 2’s fail, making this a relatively safe and informative team.

proposals.reasoning: This team keeps me consistent with wanting to minimize repeats from the failed Mission 2: it includes none of Bob, Charlie, or Frank. It reuses Eve from the successful Mission 1, which gives us at least one player with a clean result so far, and adds Grace as a single new variable who wasn’t on either prior mission. This also aligns with suggestions from both Eve and Grace for a low‑risk lineup that avoids the Mission 2 tangle while not auto‑including Bob as the overlap between success and fail.

votes.comment: I’m on the team and it fully avoids the suspicious Mission 2 trio, so it’s both strategically informative and gives us a clean test outside that tangle.
Avoids both Charlie and Frank from the failed mission while reusing Eve from a prior success; reasonable low-risk info-gathering team given what we know.
I still don’t like adding Alice here when we have the Bob/Eve success from Mission 1 to lean on; I’d rather see a team that builds off that info instead of swapping Bob out for another untested slot.
Still don’t like that this completely dodges Mission 2—would rather see at least one of Bob/Charlie/Frank included so we get clearer info instead of a totally disconnected lineup.
Consistent with my earlier preference: avoids all players from the failed Mission 2 while keeping me from the successful Mission 1 and adding only new, untested players.
No suspected evil on this team; as evil I want at least one saboteur on the mission.
Matches my preferred low-risk team: avoids all players from the failed Mission 2 while keeping Eve from the successful Mission 1 and adding only one new variable (me).

discussion.content: I don’t think we can clear Bob anymore just because Mission 1 passed—Mission 2 makes at least one of Bob/Charlie/Frank look bad, so I’d prefer a team that minimizes repeats from that group.

From my perspective we know the fail on Mission 2 came from either Charlie or Frank, since I’m good. I’d be happiest with a team that includes me plus people outside that pair—maybe bringing Eve back from the successful first mission and adding someone like Alice or Diana.

I agree we should limit repeats from Mission 2—something like Bob, Eve, and Grace feels like a solid, low‑risk lineup right now. That keeps the proven-success pair from Mission 1 and adds just one new variable instead of re-running the whole questionable group.

I’m fine with limiting repeats from Mission 2, so a team like Bob, Eve, and Grace feels reasonable to me as well, since it only carries over one person from the failed mission. If that passes cleanly, I’d be much more comfortable trusting Bob going forward.

I’m not comfortable auto‑including Bob when he’s the only overlap between the success and the fail—I’d rather see a team like me, Alice, and Grace (or Diana) so we avoid repeating too much of Mission 2.

I like the idea of minimizing repeats from the failed team, so something like Eve, Diana, and Grace feels like a reasonable compromise that avoids the Bob/Charlie/Frank tangle for now. If that passes cleanly, we’ll have a much clearer picture of where the problem on Mission 2 came from.

Given Mission 2, I’d like to keep repeats from that team to a minimum but still use what little we “know,” so I’m okay with a Bob, Eve, and me lineup as a reasonable test of Bob. If people are too nervous about Bob being the overlap, my next preference would be Eve, Alice, and me to keep things as clean as possible from the failed mission.

proposals.reasoning: Mission 2’s fail implicates at least one of {Bob, Charlie, Frank}, and since I know I’m good, the spy there is in {Charlie, Frank}. Mission 3’s fail implicates at least one of {Alice, Eve, Grace}. To maximize our odds, we avoid the most suspicious overlaps: keep both Eve and Frank (each on a failed team) off this mission entirely, and don’t stack both Alice and Grace together from the failed Mission 3 team. That leaves a broadly supported core of Bob + Charlie + Diana, plus exactly one of {Alice, Grace}. Between those, I choose Grace because it keeps us away from the Alice–Eve connection from the last failed mission and matches the majority of players’ stated preferences to anchor around Charlie and Diana while excluding Eve and Frank.

votes.comment: Keeps both Eve and Frank (each from failed missions) off the team while centering the widely trusted Charlie+Diana core plus only one of Alice/Grace, which fits the table’s stated preferences and gives us a cleaner test.
Team includes both Charlie (from the M2 fail set) and Grace (from the M3 fail set); pairing suspects from both failed missions plus an untested Diana is too risky on a must-win mission.
This still pulls one person from each of the prior fail pools (Bob from M2’s suspects and Grace from M3’s), so odds feel too high that we’re carrying at least one spy here.
This keeps both Eve and Frank (each on failed teams) off, matches the earlier consensus around Charlie and me as a core, and tests a new mix with only one of Alice/Grace from the last failed team.

Team includes both Bob and Charlie (at least one of {Bob,Charlie,Frank} is evil) plus Grace (at least one of {Alice,Grace} is evil), so from my perspective there’s a high chance of at least one spy on this team when we can’t afford another fail.
Only one evil (Diana) on the team, giving us a clean shot to sabotage and win; rejecting might produce a safer team for good.
This lineup guarantees at least one of Charlie/Diana—who look like the same hidden role—is on the wrong side; stacking both plus Bob (from a failed mission) feels too risky at 2–1 down.

proposals.reasoning: We know the two failed missions were [Bob, Charlie, Frank] and [Alice, Eve, Grace]. I want to avoid stacking too many people from either of those exact fail teams while also keeping both Alice and Diana off, since they haven’t yet been part of a successful configuration. This lineup keeps Charlie as a common point from the successful first mission and the second mission, but removes Frank (the new addition on the failed second mission) and removes Alice (the clear overlap/leader on the failed third mission). Putting Bob, Eve, and Grace together with me gives us a mixed team that avoids the most suspicious pairings (no Bob+Frank, no Alice+Eve+Grace) while still testing whether the earlier fails were caused by Frank or by combinations involving Alice, without overfitting to any single suspicion cluster.

votes.comment: High chance at least one evil is on this team given overlaps with both prior failing teams, so it’s likely to produce another fail without exposing me.

This team packs too many from the two failed missions: it includes Charlie from the Bob/Charlie/Frank fail and both Eve and Grace from the Alice/Eve/Grace fail, so it almost certainly contains at least one (and likely more) evil.
This matches the kind of mixed team I argued for earlier (Bob, me, Grace plus one of Eve/Frank) while keeping Alice and Frank off after their failed missions.
This still reuses the suspicious Eve+Grace block from the last failed mission; I’d rather avoid that cluster and include someone like Diana or Alice instead.

I know I’m good, and this keeps both Alice and Frank (each on a failed mission they led) off the team. The lineup mixes suspects from the two failing groups without recreating either exact fail team, and it’s at least plausible this could be a clean configuration.
Too many people from the previously failed missions without including me or Diana; I’d prefer a team configuration that better isolates the earlier failures.

This swaps in Eve (from a known failed team with me) and drops Diana, who is in the Merlin/Morgana pair. I’d rather keep Eve off and run something like Bob/Charlie/Diana/me, which was closer to a structurally safer team for Mission 4.

proposals.reasoning: This team avoids both previously failing clusters at the same time: we keep Eve and Frank off together, and we also avoid bringing back the full Alice–Eve–Grace trio from the last failed mission. Bob and I are each coming from different prior teams, Charlie has only been on the one failed mission with Frank and Bob, and Alice was on the last fail but without overlapping with Bob/Charlie. This composition lines up with what several of you said you were comfortable with earlier—building around Bob, Charlie, and me, plus either Alice or Grace—while giving us a cleaner read that doesn’t overload any single suspected group.

votes.comment: Fits my earlier preference to avoid the Bob–Eve combo and lean on Charlie and Diana; I’m okay testing this mix now.

This team has both Charlie (from the M2 fail with Frank) and Alice (from the M3 fail with Eve/Grace); we only need one more failed mission to lose, so I don’t want two prime suspects on the same team.
Too risky to include both Alice and Diana together when we’re on the brink; I’d prefer swapping one of them for Grace to reduce the chance of stacking an unseen evil pair.
I’m on it, and this lineup still looks consistent with earlier stated preferences while avoiding the obvious suspect clusters.

From my view there’s at least one evil in {Bob, Charlie, Frank} and at least one in {Alice, Grace}, and this team includes Bob, Charlie, and Alice, making it very likely to contain at least one (possibly two) evil players when we can still aim for a safer composition.
Mission 4 needs two fails; this team only has one evil, so it would almost certainly succeed and help the good side.

Given prior fails, we know there is at least one evil among {Bob, Frank, Charlie} and at least one among {Alice, Eve}. This team includes Bob, Charlie, and Alice, so it is guaranteed to contain at least one evil.

proposals.reasoning:
We know there is at least one evil in {Bob, Charlie, Frank} and at least one in {Alice, Grace}, and I know I’m good. I want to (1) avoid repeating full failing clusters, (2) include at most one player from each suspect group, and (3) use the untested slot on someone likely clean.

1) Avoiding known bad clusters:
- Mission 2 (Bob, Charlie, Frank) failed with 1 FAIL, so at least one of them is evil. I’ll take at most one of {Bob, Charlie, Frank} and completely exclude Frank, who only appears on the failed mission.
- Mission 3 (Alice, Eve, Grace) failed with 1 FAIL, so at least one of {Alice, Grace} is evil (since I know I’m good). I’ll include at most one of them to avoid recreating that cluster.

2) Choice within suspect groups:
- From {Bob, Charlie, Frank}, Charlie is preferable to Frank (who is only on the failed mission) and to Bob, who already appears in the earlier fail cluster with Frank. Taking Charlie lets us test him without stacking too much of that failed trio.
- From {Alice, Grace}, I choose Grace. Repeating Alice (who led and built the previously failing team) along with Charlie might over-concentrate potential evil narrative control, whereas Grace gives us a different mix from the previous fail.

3) Diana as a fresh read:
- Diana is completely untested so far and is widely treated as a neutral anchor by both sides. Including her gives us new information without pulling from any prior failing combination.

4) Myself (Eve):
- From my perspective as good, excluding myself means leaving the mission entirely in the hands of players drawn from the two failing groups, which feels worse than anchoring the team with a player I know is good.

Net effect: This team avoids Frank, doesn’t repeat the exact failing combinations from Missions 2 or 3, limits us to at most one member from each known-tainted set, and brings in Diana as fresh information. That structure maximizes our chance of a clean mission given what I know.

votes.comment: Not ideal but better than prior options: it keeps Bob and Frank off, adds Diana as fresh info, and mixes only one of the Mission 2 trio with the Mission 3 pair in a new combination.

Critical mission at 2-1 and this team skips me while including multiple players from both failing groups ({Charlie} from M2 and {Eve, Grace} from M3). From my perspective that’s too much risk and worse than a team built around me plus the safer reads like Charlie/Diana and one of Alice/Grace.
Too risky: it includes both Eve and Grace from the last failed team plus completely untested Diana. I’d rather not stack that much uncertainty when we’re already down 1–2.
I’m on the team and it excludes both Bob and Frank, which fits the current suspicion patterns and gives us fresh info without repeating known bad clusters.

I know I’m good and Diana is effectively guaranteed good; this team avoids Frank and Alice (both highly suspect), uses only one from each tainted group, and we’re already on the 4th proposal so risking a 5th led by a more suspicious player feels worse than running this mix.
I’m evil and off the team; my teammate Diana is on it and can sabotage for the win, so I want this to go through.

Eve is heavily tainted from the previous fail with me and Alice, and this team also includes Charlie from the Bob/Charlie/Frank failing trio. With the score at 1–2, I don’t want both a suspect from each fail-cluster plus me on what could be the losing mission.

discussion.content: Given the two fails, I really don’t like putting *both* Bob and Eve on the same team again, since they’re the only ones who were on a success and then on separate failing teams. I’d rather build around people who’ve only been on one failed mission at most—like Charlie or Grace—plus someone untested like Diana.

From my perspective, at least one of Eve/Frank has to be evil, and one of Alice/Grace/Eve is also evil, so I’m most comfortable building around me, Charlie, and Diana and avoiding Eve and Frank for this mission. I’d lean toward [Bob, Charlie, Diana, Alice] or [Bob, Charlie, Diana, Grace], but not both Alice and Grace together.

Given we’ve already had fails with (Bob + Frank) and with (Alice + Eve + Grace), I’d rather not stack too many people from either of those teams together again—something like Bob, me, Grace, plus one of Eve or Frank feels like a reasonable balance to test.

I’m on board with a team like Bob, Charlie, and me, plus either Alice or Grace—keeping Eve and Frank off for now gives us a cleaner test of that earlier fail without overloading from any one suspect group.

From my point of view, there’s at least one evil in {Bob/Charlie/Frank} and at least one in {Alice/Grace}, so I’d rather see something like Charlie, Diana, me, plus **one** of Alice or Grace—not both, and ideally not Bob and Frank together again.

Given the previous fails, I’m fine staying off this one, and I actually like the cleaner [Bob, Charlie, Diana, Alice] team as a way to avoid both the Eve/Grace cluster and the Bob/Frank pairing we already know is tainted.

I’d really like to anchor this team around both Charlie and Diana and keep Eve and Frank off for now—something like Charlie, Diana, me, plus either Bob or Alice feels like our best shot at a clean mission.
